texts.definition: Surprises in the game that are not related to the game diegesis.
markups: <style="Definition">Surprises in the game that are not related to the game diegesis.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> are surprises put in games that do not directly affect gameplay nor does necessarily advance any story. Often they do not even fit within the reality of the Game World. The design of <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> started as programmers' and game designers' ways of protesting against management but soon turned into a gameplay value, encouraging people to explore and replay the games.

The first documented <style="CurrentLink">Easter Egg</style> was the text "Created by Robinett." in the game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Adventure">Adventure</link></style>. It was put there by its programmer and designer, Warren Robinett. To find it, players had to find an object a single pixel large that had the same color as the background of the game and was located in a room that was inaccessible unless you used a special bridge. This object then had to be carried to a specific wall to let the players enter a secret room which contained the message.

<style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> can vary considerably in sizes. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> included entire levels as <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style>, including an underwater world that is seemingly endless. Topping this, the whole game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maniac%20Mansion">Maniac Mansion</link></style> is included as an <style="CurrentLink">Easter Egg</style> in its sequel <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Day%20of%20the%20Tentacle">Day of the Tentacle</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Star%20Trek:%20The%20Next%20Generation">Star Trek: The Next Generation</link></style> is worth mentioning since it is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Pinball%20Games">Pinball Game</link></style> with a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Breakout">Breakout</link></style>-like game as an <style="CurrentLink">Easter Egg</style>.

Game series that repeatedly make use of <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> include the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto%20series">Grand Theft Auto</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Halo%20series">Halo</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Smash%20Bros.%20series">Super Smash Bros. series</link></style>.
For more examples, see the site GiantBomb which has a listing of games with <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style>.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> consisting of what they should contain, where in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> they should exist, and making sure they are <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> are typically <style="Link"><link="secret-resources">Secret Resources</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style> (often humorous) but as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Day%20of%20the%20Tentacle">Day of the Tentacle</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Star%20Trek:%20The%20Next%20Generation">Star Trek: The Next Generation</link></style> examples show, they can also be <style="Link"><link="minigames">Minigames</link></style>. To make them a challenge to find, they are often put in <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style> which also helps maintain the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> until they are found - this lets players make a choice between searching for <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> and probably experiencing thematic inconsistency or ignore these and probably not have any thematic inconsistencies. <style="Link"><link="minigames">Minigames</link></style> that are <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> do not need to make use of <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style> since they instead change the game presentation (or part of it) when players have found the ways of activating them; this is typically through having them "hidden" in <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> or other <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> objects that can be found by sufficient <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>.
<style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> can by game designers that wish to make it likelier for players to find their <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> typically break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> since they often take the form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> are a way of providing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> in games by hiding secrets in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. They are often a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style> that breaks <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, but do encourage <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>. They add social components through creating <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> of finding the <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> before others, something that can lead to both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bragging">Bragging</link></style> and through this to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> between players. While this can occur in all types of games, the effects are more profound in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> since these may otherwise not have the patterns. The actual description of <style="CurrentLink">Easter Eggs</style> and their locations are a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> between players.

While they most often are hidden within <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style> these are typically harder to find than other <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style> in the same game are thereby support <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> to complete the <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style> of finding these. This of course assumes that players have reasons to believe they exist (which can be either due to <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> or due to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> between players).
Knowledge about their existence provides Optional Goals of Exploration and may stimulate Social Interaction between game sessions to pass Trans-Game Information.
